overview_of_class: This course will explore the history of the recording industry from the invention of the phonograph in 1877 to recent developments in digital audio. We will examine the social, cultural, and technological factors that have shaped the development of the recording industry, and consider musical genres such as jazz, blues, rock, swing, muzak, dub, techno and rap. We will consider the production, distribution, and reception of recordings, tracking the changing ways in which people have listened to music, from phonograph parlors to jukeboxes to hi-fi home stereos to iPods. The industry in recorded music will be our primary focus, but we will explore synergies with the film industry, radio, gaming, and other emergent digital forms. Some of the key themes in the course will be the intersection of sound industries; the tension between independent and major labels; questions of copyright and creativity in popular music; the relationship between technology and innovation in sound art; and the increasing mobility and cultural ubiquity of recorded sound. Looking back across the "century of sound" allows us to gain a deeper appreciation of our current immersion in recorded sound, and to understand the central debates and dynamics that have shaped the recording industry.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
By the end of the course students should be able to:

  • Understand and appreciate a wide range of sound recordings in their full historical, social, and cultural contexts.

  • Apply a historical understanding of the recording industry to current practices, companies, and artists.

  • Think critically about the role played by the recording industry in everyday social life.

  • Situate the recording industry within a broad terrain of media industries, including film, television, radio, and digital games.

  • Create an original and well-informed analysis of a significant aspect of recording history.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Students will be assessed through: 1) short response papers assigned throughout the quarter; 2) short quizzes and a final exam that cover material from class readings, lectures, and discussions; 3) a final research paper.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
David L. Morton. Sound Recording: The Life Story of a Technology (Johns Hopkins University Press, 2004).


Steve Knopper. Appetite for Self-Destruction: The Spectacular Crash of the Record Industry in the Digital Age (Soft Skull Press, 2010)


Jeremy Morris. Selling Digital Music, Formatting Culture (University of California Press, 2015)

overview_of_class: What does the study of human(s) in specific historical contexts sound like? How does situated listening help us to better understand the ways in which social relations are constituted through sound? This seminar integrates experiential learning with readings and discussions to develop ethnographic skills in listening, recording, editing and representing what John Blacking famously called "humanly organized sound." If the ethnographic process consists of gathering, interpreting and analyzing, and representing ethnographic material, we look at various case studies that analyze field recordings, oral histories, sound archives, listening practices, and commodified sounds as their primary object of study. We ask how sonic phenomena can be used to address key anthropological issues, including but not limited to sensory studies, space and place, historical ethnography, political economy, and the sonic relations of bodies and technologies. Students will be asked to design and conduct an ethnographic project that we will workshop over the course of the term.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
• to understand ethnography as a concept, method, and approach employed by the social sciences, humanities, and non-academic research industries

  • to be able to understand the role of sound in diverse modes of communication, situate these communicative encounters in specific societal contexts, and develop ethnographic insights into the relations of self, society, and sound

  • to develop skills in analyzing the representation and performance of social difference in society, and attend to the ways in which the politics of difference operates worldwide

  • to approach ethnography as a collaborative and co-performative mode of conducting research

  • to develop skills in ethnographic methods, including but not limited to oral histories, field recordings, soundwalks, digital data collection, and participant-observation

  • to read, listen, analyze, synthesize, and discuss a range of literature that discusses fieldwork conducted worldwide

  • to communicate ideas and experiences effectively through oral, written, and sound media

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value:
• 2-3 response papers assigned throughout the term

  • 1 in-class presentation

  • 1 ethnographic project to be carried out, in stages assigned by the instructor, over the course of the term

  • participation in peer assessment of ethnographic projects, at various stages

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
• books, articles, and sound media will be available through course reserves, Canvas, or for purchase

  • field recording equipment will be available through the SAI program

  • editing equipment (as needed) will be available through the SAI program
